Table 4 Total sulfur content in the product (ppm) Mercaptan content in the product (ppm) 57 22 46 21 29 19 19 13 10 9 Optimizing both the CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst and the technology for selectivity enhancement in the hydrodesulfurization of FCC gasoline Cen Zhang a b Xinyi Liu a b Tiefeng Liu a Zongxuan Jiang a Can Li a ⁎ 1 a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 http://www.canli.dicp.ac.cn. Graphical abstract Herein, a series of alumina supports were prepared by rehydration-dehydration of the traditional γ-Al2O3 under different hydrothermal temperatures. After loading CoMo species, it was found the selectivity factor of corresponding CoMo/Al2O3 catalysts was improved greatly from 1.21 to 2.51 with the increased hydrothermal temperature of alumina supports in the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of a model fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) naphtha. The improved HDS selectivity is attributed to the weakened metal-support interaction and lowered dispersion of MoS2 particles, resulting in catalysts with larger edge-to-corner ratios of CoMoS slabs ((f e/f c)CoMo). Besides, the recombination mercaptans formed by reaction of produced H2S and olefins were found as a big challenge to reach a high HDS conversion (S < 10 ppm) when only using the selective HDS catalyst (one-unit process). Therefore, a two-unit process has been developed by using a selective HDS catalyst to remove the most of the refractory sulfur compounds firstly, after which using another mercaptan-removing catalyst to deal with the recombination mercaptans specially. The catalytic results show that the two-unit process has a smaller olefin loss (4.38 v%) than that of one-unit process (7.08 v%) when reducing the sulfur concentration of a heavy FCC fraction to less than 10 ppm, thus resulting in a 0.7 unit less of the research octane number loss. The present work shows that high HDS conversion and low olefin hydrogenation conversion in selective HDS of FCC gasoline can be achieved through optimization design of both the selective HDS catalyst and the whole technology. Keywords CoMo/Al2O3 MoS2 morphology tuning Recombination mercaptan Selective HDS FCC gasoline 1 Introduction Due to the increasingly strict environmental protection legislation, refiners worldwide must produce clean gasoline of which the sulfur concentration is lower than 10 ppm. This is because the SO x exhausted by vehicles is one of the major cause for air pollution. Therefore, removing the sulfur compounds in gasoline has attracted worldwide attention in recent years [1–12]. Generally, the commercial gasoline pool is a mixture blended by many components. Among them, fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) gasoline is the most “dirty” one because it contributes approximately 85–95 wt.% of the total sulfur and a large amount of olefins to the gasoline pool [13]. Hence, the key for gasoline upgrading is to refine and reduce the sulfur content of FCC gasoline. Although there are many methods such as hydrodesulfurization (HDS), oxidative desulfurization or adsorptive desulfurization have been applied to remove the sulfur in the fuel, HDS is the most utilized technique to produce clean fuel in industry [14,15]. Alumina loaded with Co-promoted MoS2 is the commonly used catalyst in the hydro-upgrading of FCC naphtha because of its relative higher HDS activity but lower hydrogenation (HYD) activity compared with NiMo/Al2O3 or NiW/Al2O3. And, at the typical industrial reaction conditions of 250–280 °C and 1.0–2.0 MPa, deep HDS of FCC gasoline (S < 10 ppm) is easy to be achieved when the traditional CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst is used. This is because most of the sulfur-containing compounds are easily-removed molecules like thiophene and alkyl-substituted thiophenes. However, deep HDS is usually accompanied with heavy HYD of the olefins, where the situation is not desired because it will result in a great loss of octane number [16]. Thus, achieving both deep HDS and little HYD of olefins in HDS of FCC gasoline is highly desirable. Various approaches have been reported aiming to increase the HDS selectivity of conventional CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst. For example, modification of potassium was a usual method to improve the selectivity of CoMo/Al2O3 by decreasing the HYD activity more than the HDS activity [4,17,18]. The mechanism was proposed by Ishutenko et al. that potassium partially inserts into MoS2 slabs and form the new “KCoMoS” active centers [18]. Another method to improve its HDS selectivity was to increase the slab length of MoS2 particles supported on the alumina [19–21]. This can be realized by increasing the Mo loading content [22], using a less reductive sulfidation atmosphere [1] or an ex-situ sulfidation method [7]. In this way, the nature of active centers remained the same while the ratio of edge to corner sites has been increased, which decreased the amount of corner sites responsible for olefin HYD. In our previous work, we found out that the surface properties of γ-Al2O3 had a great influence on the selectivity of CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst in the hydro-upgrading of FCC gasoline. In addition, CoMo supported on a hydrothermally-treated γ-Al2O3 showed much higher HDS selectivity than the traditionally prepared CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst due to the much longer MoS2 slab length [9]. To understand the effect of hydrothermal treatment in detail, herein, a series of γ-Al2O3 materials were prepared by rehydration-dehydration of the traditional γ-Al2O3 under different hydrothermal temperatures and used as supports to prepare CoMo/Al2O3 catalysts. The influence of different alumina supports on the selectivity of as-prepared CoMo/Al2O3 catalysts in the hydro-upgrading of a model FCC naphtha was studied. Besides the catalyst, technology is also a crucial factor to improve the HDS selectivity. Therefore, developing new technology or optimizing the existing technologies which can reduce the octane number loss are also useful from practical aspects. The existing FCC gasoline hydrotreating technologies can be classified by two different strategies [13]. One is the selective HDS technology which preserves the olefins, including Prime G+ and SCANfining. The other is the octane recovery technology such as Oct-Gain, ISAL and GARDES [23]. However, selective HDS technology is the most commonly used by refineries up to now. Especially, the Prime G+ technology developed by Axens has been licensed the most worldwide. As the key of Prime G+ technology, the selective HDS unit mainly deals with the heavy fraction and contains two tailored catalysts loaded in two different reactors. The first one is a selective HDS catalyst (HR806) with high HDS activity but low HYD activity which could remove most of the refractory sulfur compounds. Another one is a mercaptan-removing catalyst (HR841) with high hydrogenolysis activity but minimum olefin HYD activity which could remove the recombination mercaptans and complete the final desulfurization. According to the literature, the mercaptan formed by produced H2S with olefins is also a challenge to reach high level of sulfur removal [13]. However, as the best as we know, most of the reported studies in this field have been conducted to increase the selectivity of CoMo/Al2O3 so far. And few researches have focused on the influence of recombination mercaptan on the whole HDS process. Herein, the another research goal of this work is to study the influence of recombination mercaptan and get better insight into the whole process which could help us to optimize the technology and reduce the octane number loss in the FCC gasoline hydro-upgrading. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of supports and catalysts Pseudo-boehmite (PB) in powder form was provided by Shandong alumina factory. Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O were obtained from Sinopharm chemical reagent company and used as received without further treatment. The traditional alumina support (denoted as Al2O3) was prepared from the direct calcination of PB powder at 550 °C for 4 h at a heating speed of 2 °C/min. The modification of Al2O3 support was carried out by hydrothermal treatment according to our previous report [9]. Specifically, the Al2O3 was hydrothermally treated at 120 °C, 150 °C, 180 °C for 4 h in a teflon-lined autoclave (200 mL) with a water/solid ratio of 30 mL/g. Then, the products were washed and dried, finally calcined at 550 °C for 4 h at a heating speed of 2 °C/min. The as-obtained Al2O3 supports were denoted as “Al2O3-x”, where x represents the hydrothermal temperature during the hydrothermal process. The CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts were prepared utilizing the successive incipient wetness impregnation method. The Al2O3-x powder supports were impregnated successively with (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O aqueous solutions. The MoO3 and CoO loading for the four CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts were 12.0 wt.% and 3.0 wt.%. The samples were dried at 70 °C overnight firstly, and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h with a heating speed of 2 °C/min after each impregnation step. The mercaptan-removing catalyst NiO/Al2O3 was prepared by impregnating the traditional alumina support with aqueous solutions of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. The NiO loading content is 18.0 wt.%. After the impregnation step, the solid was dried at 70 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h with a heating speed of 2 °C/min. 2.2 Sample characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization was performed on a PANalytical EMPYREAN powder diffractometer operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The textural properties of samples were analyzed by nitrogen physisorption on a Quantachrome system at 77 K. The specific area was calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Pore size distribution was obtained from the desorption branch of isotherms via the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Raman characterization was conducted on a Renishaw spectrometer with exciting laser wavelength of 532 nm. The analysis parameters were set as follows: power of 2 mW, exposure time of 60 s and accumulation of 10 times. The pyridine adsorption experiments were conducted on a Bruker FT-IR spectrometer. Prior to the experiments, 15 mg samples were pressed into the self-supporting disks (diameter: 1.3 cm). Typically, samples were firstly degassed under vacuum at 350 °C for 1 h. After cooled down to room temperature, the pyridine vapor was introduced into the cell. The spectra were recorded after degassing at 150 °C for 0.5 h and cooled down to the room temperature. The amount of Lewis acid sites was calculated according to the band area at 1450 cm−1 obtained from the spectra [24]. The equation is C (pyridine on L sites) = 1.42IA(L)R 2/W, where C = concentration (mmol g−1), IA(L) = integrated area of L band (cm-2), R = radius of sample disk (cm), W = weight of disk (mg). Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles of the oxidic catalysts were obtained on an instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Firstly, 30 mg samples were pretreated at 130 °C for 1 h under Ar atmosphere. Then, the temperature was raised from 130 °C to 950 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a 5 vol.% H2/Ar stream (50 mL/min). The H2 consumption was detected by the TCD. TPR of freshly sulfided catalysts (TPR-S) were performed on the same apparatus. Typically, 50 mg samples were presulfided in situ in 10 vol.% H2S/H2 (60 mL/min) at 400 °C for 2 h to avoid the oxidation. The samples were heated from 50 °C to 650 °C at a heating speed of 10 °C/min in a 5 vol.% H2/Ar stream (50 mL/min). The H2S signal was detected by a mass spectrometer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on a HITACHI HT7700 microscope at the acceleration voltage of 100 kV. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) observation of the sulfided catalysts was performed on a FEI TECNAI G2 F30 microscope with the acceleration voltage of 300 kV. Typically, at least 20 representative micrographs were obtained, including about 300 MoS2 particles taken from different parts for each sulfided catalyst. The equations for calculating the Mo dispersion (f Mo), average slab length (Lav ), average layer number (Nav ) and edge-to-corner sites ratio of MoS2 slabs ((f e/f c)Mo) were listed in the supporting information. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was conducted on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi instrument using a monochromatic Al Kα source (hν = 1486.6 eV). The four oxidic CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts were pre-sulfided at 400 °C for 3 h in a 10 vol.%H2S/H2 mixture before analysis. The data was analyzed by a XPSPEAK software. The detailed procedure for calculating the Co/Mo total atomic ratio (Co/Mo)tot, the promoter ratio in the slab edge of active phase (Co/Mo)edge and the edge-to-corner ratios of CoMoS slabs (f e/f c)CoMo was shown in the supporting information. 2.3 Catalytic performance tests The catalytic tests were performed using a home-made continuous flow, high pressure fixed-bed microreactor, and the reaction system was shown in Fig. S1. A model FCC gasoline oil which was composed of thiophene (500 ppm S), 1-hexene (20 vol. %) and n-heptane (solvent, 80 vol. %) was used as the feed. Before tests, 0.5 g oxidic catalysts (20–40 mesh) were presulfided in a 10 vol.% H2S/H2 mixture (60 mL/min) at 400 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, the reaction was conducted at conditions of 220–260 °C, 1.5 MPa, feed flow rate of 0.06 mL/min and hydrogen flow rate of 18 mL/min. After reaching a stable HDS and HYD conversion (usually 12 h), the products were sampled and analyzed. Sulfur concentration was determined by an Antek instrument with detection limit of 0.1 mg/L. The product qualitative analysis of 1-hexene hydrogenation reaction was conducted with an Agilent 7890B GCMS instrument and the standard samples. As shown in Fig. S2, there are five products of 1-hexene HYD reaction, where the hexane is the HYD product while the trans-2-hexene, cis-2-hexene, trans-3-hexene and cis-3-hexene are the double-bond isomerization products (detailed gas chromatography spectra see Fig. S3). The quantitative analysis of the liquid products was performed using an Agilent 6890N GC with a 100 m nonpolar HP-1 capillary column. To separate the different compounds, the oven temperature program was set as follows: maintained at 35 °C for 3 min, increased to 55 °C at the heating speed of 0.5 °C/min, then increased to 90 °C at the heating speed of 2 °C/min, finally increased to 200 °C at the heating speed of 10 °C/min. The total HDS conversion (CHDS), 1-hexene conversion (C1-hexene), hexane selectivity (Shexane), double-bond isomerization selectivity (SISO) and 1-hexene HYD conversion (CHYD) were calculated using Eqs. (1)–(5): (1) C HDS ( % ) = S f − S p S f × 100 (2) C 1-hexene ( % ) = 1-hexen e f − 1-hexen e p 1-hexen e f × 100 (3) S hexane ( % ) = hexa ( hexa + t r a n s -2-hexe + c i s -2-hexe + t r a n s -3-hexe + c i s -3-hexe ) × 100 (4) S ISO ( % ) = t r a n s -2-hexe + c i s -2-hexe + t r a n s -3-hexe + c i s -3-hexe hexa + t r a n s -2-hexe + c i s -2-hexe + t r a n s -3-hexe + c i s -2-hexe × 100 (5) C HYD ( % ) = C 1-hexene × S hexane The Sf and Sp in above equations represent the total sulfur concentration of feed and products, the 1-hexene f and 1-hexene p represent the 1-hexene content (wt.%) in the feed and products. The hexa, trans-2-hexe, cis-2-hexe, trans-3-hexe and cis-3-hexe represent the hexane, trans-2-hexene, cis-2-hexene, trans-3-hexene and cis-3-hexene content (wt.%) in the products, respectively. The HDS/HYD selectivity factor (SF) was calculated according to equation (6): (6) SF = ln ( 1 − C HDS ) ln ( 1 − C HYD ) 2.4 Comparison of one-unit process and two-unit process Generally, only the heavy fraction rather than the full-range FCC naphtha needs to do the hydro-upgrading process in order to reduce the olefin hydrogenation loss [2,25]. Thus, a real FCC heavy fraction (properties see Table S1) was utilized as feed to compare the performance of one-unit process and two-unit process. Typically, for the one-unit process only using the selective HDS catalyst, 10 mL CoMo/Al2O3-180 catalysts (20–40 mesh) were loaded in the middle zone of the reactor. After presulfiding for 4 h at 400 °C using 10 vol.%H2S/H2 (60 mL/min), the reaction was performed at conditions: 270 °C, 2.0 MPa, liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) 2 h−1 and H2/feed volumetric ratio of 200 Ncm3/cm3. For the two-unit process using selective HDS catalyst coupled with mercaptan-removing catalyst, a fixed-bed apparatus with two tandem reactors was used. Typically, in the first selective HDS reactor, 10 mL CoMo/Al2O3-180 catalysts (20–40 mesh) were loaded, and the reaction conditions were set as: 250 °C, 2.0 MPa, LHSV 2 h−1 and H2/feed volumetric ratio of 200 Ncm3/cm3. In the second reactor for mercaptan-removing, 10 mL NiO/Al2O3 catalysts (20–40 mesh) were loaded, the reaction conditions were set as: 320 °C, 2.0 MPa, LHSV 2 h−1 and H2/feed volumetric ratio of 200 Ncm3/cm3. Before reaction, both the two catalysts were presulfided for 4 h at 400 °C using 10 vol.%H2S/H2 (60 mL/min). The products were sampled every 8 h, and the total sulfur concentration was measured using an Antek instrument. The mercaptan content in the products were determined by the potentiometric titration method according to ASTM-D3227 [26]. An Agilent 6890 N GC installed with a 50 m HP-PONA capillary column and a flame ionization detector (FID) was used to analyze the hydrocarbon compositions. The oven temperature program was the same with our previous study [9]. The research octane number (RON) value was calculated based on the hydrocarbon composition utilizing a software purchased from SINOPEC. The identification of different sulfur-containing compounds were conducted by an Agilent 7890B GC installed with a 50 m HP-PONA capillary column and a flame photometric detector (FPD). The oven temperature was set as follows: started from 40 and maintained for 2 min, then increased to 160 °C at a speed of 2 °C/min, finally heated to 220 °C at a speed of 5 °C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Al2O3-x supports The XRD patterns of initial pseudo-boehmite (PB) and the rehydrated samples obtained at different hydrothermal temperatures without calcination are shown in Fig. 1 a. Al2O3-150-HT and Al2O3-180-HT exhibit typical diffraction peaks corresponding to the PB phase (JCPDS card No. 83-2834). While for Al2O3-120-HT, there are two another diffraction peaks at 2θ = 45.8° and 67.0° indexed to the γ-Al2O3 phase. This indicates the starting alumina materials have reacted with water and undergone a rehydration process during the hydrothermal treatment [27]. And, at a hydrothermal time of 4 h, the hydrothermal temperature should be higher than 120 °C to totally complete the rehydration process. With the increased hydrothermal temperature, the intensity of diffraction peaks become more intensive, indicating high temperature is favorable for the rehydration of alumina and the crystallites growth of the rehydrated samples. As can be seen in Fig. 1b, the diffraction peaks of all the four alumina supports after calcination of the hydrothermally treated samples could be assigned to pure γ-Al2O3 phase (JCPDS card No. 10-0425). Besides, the crystallinity and crystallite size of Al2O3-x samples also increased with elevated hydrothermal temperature, as evidenced by the enhanced peak intensity and decreased full width at half maximum. This is because dehydration from PB to alumina is only a topotactic transformation process. Change of textual properties for Al2O3-x supports were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption experiments. Fig. S4a exhibits that all samples have typical isotherms of type IV and hysteresis loops of type H3, which are usually found in mesoporous materials with slit shape pores according to the classification of IUPAC [28]. As listed in Table 1 , both the surface areas and total pore volumes of Al2O3-x supports are decreased from 282 to 90 m2/g and 0.87 to 0.38 cm3/g while the average pore sizes increase from 7.9 to 23.2 nm with the increased hydrothermal temperature. Obviously, the modification of textual properties is related to the change of the particle size and shape. The increased crystallite size of the alumina samples characterized by XRD and TEM images (Fig. S5) leads to the decrease of specific surface areas. On the other hand, the thickness and lateral size of alumina nanocrystallites with plate-like structure are increased with the increased hydrothermal temperature, in accompany with the shape changing from fiber to rhomboid with different sizes. Due to the increase of crystallite size and the more disordered structure, the pore size distributions become broader and the average pore sizes are increased. The surface acidity of γ-Al2O3 which originates from the surface hydroxyl groups and the coordinatively unsaturated aluminum ions derived from dehydration, is of great importance to adjust the metal-support interaction (MSI) [29–31]. Hence, the effect of hydrothermal treatment under different temperatures on the surface acidity of four γ-Al2O3 supports were analyzed by pyridine FT-IR. Obviously, four bands at 1450, 1492, 1578 and 1615 cm−1 in the range of 1400-1700 cm-1 are observed (Fig. 2 ), which can be attributed to the pyridine adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites according to the reports [32]. The absence of adsorption band at 1540 cm-1 suggests no Brønsted acid sites are formed after the hydrothermal and subsequent calcination process. In addition, there is an obvious decrease of the peak areas with the increased hydrothermal temperature, and the calculated total Lewis acidity is decreased in the order of Al2O3 (196 μmol g-1) > Al2O3-120 (168 μmol g-1) > Al2O3-150 (93 μmol g-1) > Al2O3-180 (80 μmol g-1). The acid site density was also calculated and increased with the increased hydrothermal temperature (Table S2). In a previous work, Li et al. also reported that alumina supports obtained from rehydration-dehydration with rehydration temperature lowered than 200 °C showed decreased total Lewis acidity and increased acid site density [27]. The decreased total Lewis acidity is because higher hydrothermal temperature improves the crystallinity of alumina support, thus resulting in the decreased amount of surface hydroxyl groups and the number of coordinatively unsaturated aluminum ions. 3.2 Characterization and catalytic evaluation of CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts Fig. 1c shows the XRD patterns of oxidic CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts. After impregnating the different alumina supports with cobalt and molybdenum, followed with drying and calcination, no other crystalline phases (MoO3 or CoO) except for the alumina phase are detected on the CoMo/Al2O3 and CoMo/Al2O3-120 samples which indicates that the metal species have a high dispersion on the surface of Al2O3 and Al2O3-120. However, for the samples of CoMo/Al2O3-150 and CoMo/Al2O3-180, some other peaks at 2θ = 23.3°, 26.6° and 33.7° which correspond to the β-CoMoO4 phase [33] are found. This indicates that the Mo species has exceeded the monolayer dispersion. The calculated Mo loading density for CoMo/Al2O3-150 and CoMo/Al2O3-180 is 4.9 and 6.3 atoms/nm2 (Table 1), which is higher than the MoO3 monolayer surface coverage (about 4.6 Mo atoms/nm2) on Al2O3 support according to the literature [34]. In addition, the crystallite size of β-CoMoO4 of CoMo/Al2O3-180 is larger than that of CoMo/Al2O3-150, evidenced by the increased peak intensity of β-CoMoO4 phase. After loading Co and Mo, the mesopores are still present in the catalyst (Fig. S4b), but the specific areas, pore volumes and average pore sizes (Table 1) are decreased due to the metal filling into the pore channels. Fig. 3 displays the Raman spectra of four oxidic CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts which give us information about the state of metal species. The peaks located at 942 and 947 cm−1 of CoMo/Al2O3 and CoMo/Al2O3-120 are attributed to the symmetric stretching vibration of Mo=O bond, and the peak at 847 cm−1 is ascribed to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of Mo-O-Mo bridge bond in the polymolybdate species [35]. Besides, the existence of polymolybdate species suggests that the Mo-oxygen species are well dispersed on the Al2O3 and Al2O3-120 surface, in consistent with the XRD analysis. These well-dispersed polymolybdate species with Mo in octahedral coordination are reported to interact weakly with the alumina support and easily to he reduced and sulfided, thus resulting in higher HDS activity. The peak located at 692 cm−1 for CoMo/Al2O3, CoMo/Al2O3-120 and CoMo/Al2O3-150 is attributed to the Co3O4 species [36]. For CoMo/Al2O3-150 and CoMo/Al2O3-180 samples, the peaks observed at 817, 939 and 950 cm−1 are assigned to the β-CoMoO4 species according to the literature [9]. Additionally, the peak intensities of oxidic CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts are enhanced with the increased hydrothermal temperature, suggesting the gradually lowered Mo dispersion. To study the reduction information of metal species and the MSI of CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts, H2-TPR analysis was carried out and the spectra is displayed in Fig. 4 . All the oxidic CoMo/Al2O3-x samples exhibit two reduction regions in the temperature interval of 400–600 °C and 600–1000 °C. The low-temperature reduction peaks are assigned to the reduction of well-dispersed octahedral Mo species weakly interacted with the alumina support (Mo6+ + 2e → Mo4+) [37,38]. This peak temperature is a good indication of MSI between the metal species and support. As shown in Fig. 4, CoMo/Al2O3 and CoMo/Al2O3-120 have the same reduction temperature at 487 °C, indicating the similar MSI for the two samples. However, the peak shifts to lower temperature for CoMo/Al2O3-150 (478 °C) and CoMo/Al2O3-180 (476 °C), which suggests that the MSI is decreased gradually with the increased hydrothermal temperature. In order to eliminate the effect of different surface areas of alumina supports, four oxidic Mo/Al2O3-x catalysts with the same Mo loading density (2.0 Mo atoms/nm2) were prepared and characterized by TPR (Fig. S6). It is found that Mo/Al2O3 (488 °C) and Mo/Al2O3-120 (488 °C) have similar peak temperature in the low-temperature reduction region, while Mo/Al2O3-150 (477 °C) and Mo/Al2O3-180 (475 °C) show gradually decreased peak temperature. The gradually weakened MSI of CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts with the increased hydrothermal temperature was attributed to the decreased amount of surface hydroxyl groups [32,39,40]. The high-temperature peaks are attributed to the reduction (Mo4+ + 4e → Mo°) of tetrahedrally-coordinated Mo species. Besides, shoulder peaks at 525 °C for CoMo/Al2O3-150 and 564 °C for CoMo/Al2O3-180 in the low temperature region are observed which are ascribed to the partial reduction of β-CoMoO4 to Co2Mo3O8 [31]. Besides, the higher reduction temperature of β-CoMoO4 phase for CoMo/Al2O3-180 (564 °C) is higher than that of CoMo/Al2O3-150 (525 °C) due to the larger β-CoMoO4 crystallite size characterized by the XRD and Raman analysis. The change of TPR patterns further confirms that the properties of alumina could affect the MSI between alumina and the supported metal species. The morphology of MoS2 particles has a great influence on the HDS activity and selectivity of (Co)Mo/Al2O3 catalysts. To get information about the morphology change of MoS2 particles, the four freshly sulfided CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts were observed by HRTEM. The corresponding HRTEM images and histograms of MoS2 length and stacking number distribution of the sulfided CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . It is found that there is remarkable difference of the MoS2 slab length and stacking number with the change of alumina supports. The CoMo/Al2O3 and CoMo/Al2O3-120 catalysts have a larger amount of monolayer MoS2 slabs than CoMo/Al2O3-150 and CoMo/Al2O3-180 due to the strong MSI. With the increase of hydrothermal temperature on the alumina supports, the MoS2 slab length and stacking gradually increase because of the decreased surface areas and weakened MSI. The detailed data in Table 2 show the average MoS2 slab length increases in the order: CoMo/Al2O3 (2.4 nm) < CoMo/Al2O3-120 (3.0 nm) < CoMo/Al2O3-150 (3.9 nm) < CoMo/Al2O3-180 (4.6 nm), and the average stacking number increases: CoMo/Al2O3 (1.7) < CoMo/Al2O3-120 (1.9) < CoMo/Al2O3-150 (2.5) < CoMo/Al2O3-180 (3.0). The f Mo values decrease in the order CoMo/Al2O3 (0.41) > CoMo/Al2O3-120 (0.35) > CoMo/Al2O3-150 (0.29) > CoMo/Al2O3-180 (0.24), in consistent with the XRD and Raman results. The key step for HDS reaction is reduction of the active sulfur species at the edge planes to produce sulfur vacancies, where the sulfur compounds could adsorb on and participate in the reaction [41]. Therefore, TPR-S experiments were performed to get information about the active sites. As displayed in Fig. 6 , there are two reduction regions corresponded to the reduction of different sulfur species. The low-temperature peaks with high intensity originate from hydrogenation of the surface sulfur species to create the sulfur vacancies, and the high-temperature peaks with low intensity result from the partial reduction of small MoS2 polycrystal in bulk phase [42]. The close reduction temperatures in the low temperature region indicate the nature of active sites are similar for the four different sulfided catalysts. However, the peak areas decrease in the order: CoMo/Al2O3 > CoMo/Al2O3-120 > CoMo/Al2O3-150 > CoMo/Al2O3-180, which means the amount of active centers is decreased gradually. The sulfidation degree of Mo species and the CoMoS phase ratio of four sulfided catalysts were determined by XPS characterization. Fig. S7 shows the deconvolution of Mo3d and Co2p3/2 spectra according to the reported literatures [43,44]. The Mo3d spectra can be deconvoluted into the following species: MoS2 (Mo3d5/2 229.0 eV, Mo3d3/2 232.1 eV), MoO x S y (Mo3d5/2 230.2 eV, Mo3d3/2 233.3 eV), Mo6+ (Mo3d5/2 232.2 eV, Mo3d3/2 235.3 eV) and sulfur (2s 226.1 eV). The sulfidation degree of Mo species was defined as the ratio of MoS2 to the sum of MoS2, MoO x S y (Mo5+) and Mo6+. As listed in Table 3 , the Mo sulfidation degree is increased in the order: CoMo/Al2O3 (71.1%) < CoMo/Al2O3-120 (71.6%) < CoMo/Al2O3-150 (76.0%) < CoMo/Al2O3-180 (80.4%). This is because CoMo/Al2O3 has a close MSI with CoMo/Al2O3-120, and the MSI is weakened gradually with the increased hydrothermal temperature as evidenced by the TPR results. The Co2p3/2 spectra was deconvoluted into three species: Co9S8 (778.1 eV), CoMoS (778.6 eV) and Co2+ (781.5 eV), and the other peaks are their corresponding satellites. The quantities of Co species in the CoMoS phase on the four catalysts are decreased gradually in the order: CoMo/Al2O3 (68.9%) > CoMo/Al2O3-120 (65.5%) > CoMo/Al2O3-150 (61.6%) > CoMo/Al2O3-180 (56.4%), in consistent with the TPR-S results. In addition, the Co9S8 phase contents are increased in the reverse order: CoMo/Al2O3 (5.7%) < CoMo/Al2O3-120 (8.9%) < CoMo/Al2O3-150 (13.6%) < CoMo/Al2O3-180 (17.1%). The reason can be explained as follows. CoMo/Al2O3 and CoMo/Al2O3-120 have the same MSI but CoMo/Al2O3 has a higher Mo dispersion than CoMo/Al2O3-120, thus leading to a larger amount of active centers for CoMo/Al2O3. For catalysts CoMo/Al2O3-150 and CoMo/Al2O3-180, although the MSI is decreased and the Mo sulfidation degree is increased with the elevated hydrothermal temperature, their MoS2 crystallites are much larger than that of CoMo/Al2O3 and CoMo/Al2O3-120. The smaller Moedge/Mototal ratio as crystallite size increases means that a smaller proportion of the cobalt can be accommodated at the edges [39,45], thus resulting in fewer Co-Mo-S active sites. The as-synthesized CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts were assessed in the hydro-upgrading of a model FCC naphtha which consists of thiophene as sulfur model compound and 1-hexene as olefin model compound. Fig. 7 shows the variation of CHDS, CHYD and SF with the reaction temperature for the four different CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts (detailed reaction data see Table S3). Firstly, in the whole temperature region from 220 °C to 250 °C, both the HDS and HYD conversions are decreased in the order of CoMo/Al2O3 > CoMo/Al2O3-120 > CoMo/Al2O3-150 > CoMo/Al2O3-180, indicating the total amount of active sites for sulfided CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts are decreased with the increased hydrothermal temperature of the alumina support. This result is in good agreement with the amount of active sites determined by XPS and TPR-S analysis. However, the HDS/HYD selectivity factors exhibit an opposite trend and are increased with the order of CoMo/Al2O3 < CoMo/Al2O3-120 < CoMo/Al2O3-150 < CoMo/Al2O3-180. At 240 °C, the HDS conversion for CoMo/Al2O3 is 96.9% and higher than that of CoMo/Al2O3-180 (80.6%), whereas the HYD conversion of CoMo/Al2O3 is 95.6% and nearly two times larger than CoMo/Al2O3-180 (48.0%). Thus, the HDS selectivity factor is increased remarkably from 1.21 for CoMo/Al2O3 to 2.51 for CoMo/Al2O3-180. This indicates the HDS selectivity is improved at the sacrifice of the HDS activity. According to previous studies [1,7,19,21,22], the HDS selectivity of CoMo/Al2O3 catalysts was increased linearly with the edge-to-corner ratio of MoS2 slabs (f e/f c)Mo. However, this factor did not take the promotion degree or the amount of CoMoS phase into consideration. In order to overcome this disadvantage, the edge-to-corner ratio of CoMoS slabs (f e/f c)CoMo was reported as a better factor to correlate with the HDS selectivity of CoMo/Al2O3 catalysts [4,18,30,46]. Table 3 shows that both the promoter ratios in the slab edge of active phase (Co/Mo)edge and the edge-to-corner ratios of CoMoS slabs (f e/f c)CoMo are increased in the order: CoMo/Al2O3 < CoMo/Al2O3-120 < CoMo/Al2O3-150 < CoMo/Al2O3-180. The correlation between the HDS/HYD selectivity factors obtained at 240 °C and the (f e/f c)CoMo values of the four catalysts is shown in Scheme 1 . The good linear fitting result suggests that catalysts with larger (f e/f c)CoMo values have higher HDS selectivity in the HDS of FCC gasoline. The highest HDS selectivity of CoMo/Al2O3-180 is due to the greatly weakened MSI and decreased MoS2 dispersion, resulting in much longer MoS2 slabs which enable the catalyst has a relatively lower HDS activity but a much lower HYD activity. More importantly, the olefin HYD saturation degree of CoMo/Al2O3-180 at 260 °C is 11% less than CoMo/Al2O3 at 240 °C (Table S3) even reaching a high and close sulfur removal (˜ 96%), suggesting its good ability to retain the olefins at high HDS conversion. With the reaction temperature increased from 220 to 260 °C, both the HDS and HYD activities are increased for all the catalysts. However, the selectivity factors pass through a maximum at 230 °C for CoMo/Al2O3 and CoMo/Al2O3-120, and at 240 °C for CoMo/Al2O3-150 and CoMo/Al2O3-180. In addition, the HDS conversions for all the catalysts at the highest HDS selectivity are about 80%, where the sulfur content in the product is about 100 ppm. This phenomenon can be explained by that the olefin HYD activity is increased much slowly than HDS activity at sulfur content higher than 100 ppm, while the olefin saturation occurs significantly at sulfur content below 100 ppm, in agreement with the previous reports [13]. Based on this characteristic, our group has developed a combination technology named “YD-CADS” which has been successfully commercialized in a refinery with a capacity of 400,000 t/a in Shandong province (China) in 2015. As shown in Fig. S8, the core of this combination technology mainly consists of two reaction units. One is the selective HDS reactor loaded with the CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst, and the other is the fix-bed adsorption desulfurization (ADS) reactor using the Ni/ZnO adsorbents. In the first selective HDS reactor, the sulfur concentration of the heavy FCC fraction is reduced to 80–100 ppm, thus reaching the highest HDS selectivity of the CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst and also making the adsorbents in the ADS unit does not need to be regenerated too frequently (usually regenerated every 3 months). This combination unit has been operated steady for three years and produced FCC gasoline meeting the national V standard which the sulfur concentration is less than 10 ppm. Besides, this technology can deal with FCC gasoline with a high sulfur content (S: 800–1500 ppm) and high olefin content (30–45 v%) while obtaining a very small RON loss (less than 2.0 units). 3.3 Influence of recombination mercaptan and optimization of the HDS technology Another important issue that could not be ignored is the mercaptan produced from the recombination of H2S with olefins. This means although we have made great efforts to extract sulfur out from the sulfur-containing compounds, however, the produced H2S reacts with olefins and form other sulfur-containing molecules. It should be noted that this recombination process is very easy to happen thermodynamically under mild reaction conditions. Therefore, it provides a relatively high concentration of recombination mercaptans and is a serious barrier for producing FCC gasoline with ultra-low sulfur content (S < 10 ppm). In order to solve this problem, the “Prime G+” technology of Axens using two reactors loading different catalysts to treat the heavy FCC fraction. In the first selective HDS reactor, a CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst is used to remove most of the refractory sulfur-containing molecules. In the second reactor, a catalyst with high hydrogenolysis activity but minimum olefin hydrogenation activity is used to remove the recombination mercaptans and complete the final desulfurization. As far as we know, the problem of recombination mercaptan has been rarely investigated in the literature. Hence, in order to help us to get deep insight into the total HDS process, the influence of recombination mercaptan was studied in this work. Firstly, the total sulfur contents and the amount of mercaptans in the products at different HDS conversions were determined. As can be seen in Table 4 , when only using CoMo/Al2O3-180 as the catalyst and a real FCC heavy fraction as the feed, the mercaptans become the major sulfur-containing compounds when the total sulfur concentration is below 30 ppm. Especially, nearly all the left sulfur-containing compounds are mercaptans with total sulfur concentration below 10 ppm. According to this characteristic, the NiO/Al2O3 catalyst which was used to remove the mercaptans in the literature [47] is utilized to deal with the mercaptans specially. The XRD patterns (Fig. 9 a) exhibit the major phase of both the freshly sulfided and spent NiO/Al2O3 catalysts is Ni3S2. Usually, Ni x S y and Co x S y phase were considered as inactive, and only act the role to provide spillover hydrogen in the remote control model [48,49]. However, the TPR profile (Fig. 9b) shows there is a strong reduction peak at 291 °C, indicating a high temperature is essential for it to be active. Due to the much lower reduction temperature of CoMo/Al2O3 catalysts (215 °C), the mismatch of working temperature for the selective HDS and the mercaptan-removing catalysts makes them could not be loaded into one reactor. Therefore, the catalytic performance of one-unit process using only CoMo/Al2O3-180 and two-unit process using catalyst combination of CoMo/Al2O3-180 and NiO/Al2O3 loaded in two tandem reactors for HDS of a real FCC heavy fraction were compared (Scheme 2 and Table S5). As can be seen in Fig. 8, when only using the selective HDS catalyst CoMo/Al2O3-180 to reduce the sulfur concentration of feed to 10 ppm directly, the olefins are reduced from 18.08 v% to 11.0 v% with the accompanying RON decreased from 84.1 to 82.0. However, for two-unit process, if we lower the reaction temperature of selective HDS unit to make the product sulfur concentration of this reactor is about 40 ppm, the olefin content in the product is firstly decreased from 18.08 v% to 14.95 v% (Fig. 10 a). Then the product of selective HDS unit is further treated in a mercaptan-removing unit; the sulfur concentration of the final product is 7.5 ppm and the olefins are reduced from 14.95 v% to 13.70 v% with the accompanying RON decreased from 84.1 to 82.7 (Fig. 10b). Obviously, the two-unit process is much more advantageous for reducing the RON loss of whole process. Since the total olefin loss of two-unit process is 4.38 v% and much lower than that of the one-unit process which has a total olefin loss of 7.08 v% even at a higher HDS conversion. Consequently, RON loss of 1.4 unit is obtained for two-unit process, and smaller than that of one-unit process which has a RON loss of 2.1 unit. In a recent report [2], Shan et al. used a real heavy FCC fraction with sulfur concentration of 367 ppm and olefin content of 30.3 v% as feed and reported a RON loss of 4.0 unit when reducing the sulfur to 10.3 ppm. Obviously, our result of two-unit process has a higher HDS conversion while a much smaller RON loss than them. Besides, no obvious deactivation was observed after testing for 56 h, indicating both the selective HDS catalyst and the mercaptan-removing catalyst have good stability. With regard to the sulfur species in the final product, nearly all the left sulfur-containing compounds are mercaptans, and no thiophene or methyl-substituted thiophene were detected for one-unit process (Table 4 and Fig. S9b). While for two-unit process, the left sulfur-containing compounds in the final product are C1-substituted thiophene, trace amount of C2-substituted thiophene and C3-substituted thiophene (Fig. S9d). This phenomenon shows that although the two final products have similar sulfur concentration, the left sulfur-containing species are totally different by using different HDS technologies. Furthermore, we changed the reaction temperature of the selective HDS reactor to make the effluent entering into the mercaptan-removing unit have different sulfur concentration. As can be seen from Fig. S10, when product sulfur concentration of the selective HDS unit is about 48 ppm, the final product has a sulfur concentration of 10.5 ppm. If the product sulfur concentration of selective HDS unit is further increased to 80 ppm, the sulfur concentration of final product is 21 ppm; even the reaction temperature of mercaptan-removing unit was increased from 320 °C to 340 °C, the sulfur concentration of final product just decreases slightly form 21 ppm to 15 ppm. Additionally, the left sulfur-containing compounds in the final product are mainly C1-thiophene and small amounts of thiophene, C2-thiophene and C3-thiophene which are difficult to be removed by the mercaptan-removing catalysts (Fig. S9f). That is to say, the product sulfur concentration of the selective HDS unit should be less than 40 ppm if we want to make the sulfur concentration of the final product less than 10 ppm. Why the two-unit process is more efficient in reducing the RON loss than one-unit process? As could be seen from Table S4, the thiophene HDS conversion and olefin HYD activity of the mercaptan-removing catalyst NiO/Al2O3 are much lower than that of the selective HDS catalyst CoMo/Al2O3-180 at their corresponding reaction conditions. Besides, results in Section 3.2 show that the olefin HYD activity is increased significantly for CoMo/Al2O3-x selective HDS catalysts when the sulfur concentration in product is less than 100 ppm. Even though the CoMo/Al2O3-180 shows higher HDS selectivity than traditional CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst, it still has 7.08 v% total olefin loss when decreasing the sulfur content to 10 ppm directly in one-unit process. However, for two-unit process, if we lower the HDS conversion in the first selective HDS unit and make its product sulfur concentration is about 40 ppm, the olefin loss is only 3.13 v% in first step. In the second unit, the mercaptan-removing catalyst with high hydrogenolysis activity but low hydrogenation activity removes nearly all the mercaptans and a small part of the alkyl-substituted thiophenes, leaving most of the alkyl-substituted thiophenes which are relatively difficult to be removed compared with mercaptans in the final product. Thus, in the second step, the sulfur concentration is reduced from 40 ppm to an ultra-low content with 7.5 ppm while the olefin loss is only 1.25 v%. Consequently, the total olefin loss for two-unit process is 4.38 v% and much lower than one-unit process, which provides us a good example in how to reduce the RON loss by optimizing the HDS technology. 4 Conclusions In present work, a series of γ-Al2O3 supports were prepared by the hydrothermal treatment at different temperatures. It was found the crystallite size and pore size of γ-Al2O3 supports increased while the surface area, pore volumes and the total Lewis acidity decreased with the increased hydrothermal temperature. The selectivity of CoMo/Al2O3-x catalysts was enhanced by sacrificing the HDS activity with the increased hydrothermal temperature of alumina support. The enhanced selectivity is interpreted by the increased slab length of MoS2 particles and edge-to-corner ratios of CoMoS slabs (f e/f c)CoMo which are caused by the decreased surface area and gradually weakened MSI. In addition, in the hydro-upgrading of a real heavy FCC fraction, we found that the left 10 ppm sulfur-containing compounds in the final product are nearly all mercaptans and the accompanying olefin loss is 7.08 v% when only using a single CoMo/Al2O3-180 selective HDS catalyst. However, through reducing the sulfur concentration to 40 ppm firstly utilizing a CoMo/Al2O3-180 selective HDS catalyst, after which using a NiO/Al2O3 catalysts with high hydrogenolysis activity but low hydrogenation activity to remove all the recombination mercaptans and a small part of the alkyl-substituted thiophenes, the sulfur concentration in the final product is 7.5 ppm (with alkyl-substituted thiophenes left) and the accompanying olefin loss is only 4.38 v%. Therefore, the two-unit process has higher HDS conversion and smaller RON loss (1.4 unit) than that of one-unit process (2.1 unit). coredata.dc:description: Herein, a series of alumina supports were prepared by rehydration-dehydration of the traditional γ-Al2O3 under different hydrothermal temperatures. After loading CoMo species, it was found the selectivity factor of corresponding CoMo/Al2O3 catalysts was improved greatly from 1.21 to 2.51 with the increased hydrothermal temperature of alumina supports in the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of a model fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) naphtha. The improved HDS selectivity is attributed to the weakened metal-support interaction and lowered dispersion of MoS2 particles, resulting in catalysts with larger edge-to-corner ratios of CoMoS slabs ((f e/f c)CoMo). Besides, the recombination mercaptans formed by reaction of produced H2S and olefins were found as a big challenge to reach a high HDS conversion (S < 10 ppm) when only using the selective HDS catalyst (one-unit process). Therefore, a two-unit process has been developed by using a selective HDS catalyst to remove the most of the refractory sulfur compounds firstly, after which using another mercaptan-removing catalyst to deal with the recombination mercaptans specially. The catalytic results show that the two-unit process has a smaller olefin loss (4.38 v%) than that of one-unit process (7.08 v%) when reducing the sulfur concentration of a heavy FCC fraction to less than 10 ppm, thus resulting in a 0.7 unit less of the research octane number loss. The present work shows that high HDS conversion and low olefin hydrogenation conversion in selective HDS of FCC gasoline can be achieved through optimization design of both the selective HDS catalyst and the whole technology.
coredata.dc:title: Optimizing both the CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst and the technology for selectivity enhancement in the hydrodesulfurization of FCC gasoline
